title.text: MathLingBudapest: Concept Networks for Semantic Similarity

abstractContent.text: We present our approach to measuring semantic similarity of sentence pairs used in Se-meval 2015 tasks 1 and 2.
We adopt the sentence alignment framework of (Han et al., 2013) and experiment with several measures of word similarity.
We hybridize the common vector-based models with definition graphs from the 4lang concept dictionary and devise a measure of graph similarity that yields good results on training data.

We did not address the specific challenges posed by Twitter data, and this is reflected in placing 11th from 30 in Task 1, but our systems perform fairly well on the generic datasets of Task 2, with the hybrid approach placing 11th among 78 runs.

To compute the semantic similarity of two sentences we use the architecture presented in) to find, for each word, its counterpart in the other sentence that is semantically most similar to it.

We implemented several methods for measuring word similarity, among them (i) a word embedding created by the method presented in ( and (ii) a metric based on networks of concepts derived from the 4lang concept lexicon and definitions from the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English.
A hybrid system exploiting both of these metrics yields the best results and placed 11th among 73 systems on Semeval Task 2a (Semantic Textual Similarity for English).
